newsitem.title: USA: Wilmington police face marchers calling for reform.
newsitem.headline: Wilmington police face marchers calling for reform.

text.p: About 400 people marched on Wilmington police headquarters Sunday to demand reform after a week of racial tension that forced the city's first black police chief to step down.
The marchers, many singing hymns and holding palm fronds to mark Palm Sunday, called on officials to examine what they said was a pattern of excessive police force against minorities.
The charges sprang from a confrontation Tuesday in which the Rev. Lawrence Livingston, a black Methodist pastor, was arrested after a scuffle with white patrolman Kurtis Crawford.

Livingston, 39, was ticketed by Crawford for running a stop sign and a red light. In Crawford's affidavit, he said he was forced to unholster his gun, use pepper spray and his police baton after Livingston became aggressive.

The dispute led Wilmington's first black mayor, James Sills, to sack Chief Samuel Pratcher, a 25-year veteran and the first black to head the force, Friday after he refused to remove Crawford from active duty until an investigation into the incident was completed.
"It was in the best interest of the officer and the community for him to be removed from street duty," Sills said Sunday.
A source close to the police said there had been anonymous telephone threats against Crawford, who has since been reassigned to administrative duty.

Although Livingston has not filed a complaint, claims of excessive force by a local church coalition and NAACP state president Keith Booker have triggered a federal investigation into possible civil rights violations and a renewed call by Mayor Sills for a police civilian review board.
Although about half of Wilmington's 73,000 residents are black, only about 36 percent of the police force come from minority groups.
